Reviews.Title: Fuji J28, a simple camera for the budget-minded person
Reviews.Author: Yarii
Reviews.Content: My first digital camera was a Fuji 2 MP bought in October 2004 - I still own that camera and it works great, but -- I love this new Fuji Finepix J28 even more, but only for the simplicity of use this camera affords.If you like manual settings on a camera, you will not be happy with this camera.  This camera is for the person who is looking for a simple-to-use point & shoot camera. In the Manual Mode, you can only change the ISO setting (from 100 to 3200), exposure value and white balance--that's it.In my opinion, the Fuji FinePix J28 goes head-to-head with the Canon Powershot A480, (which I ordered previously and returned) the Canon being a little more expensive, although prices can vary day to day. Canon PowerShot A480 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.3x Optical Zoom and 2.5-inch LCD (Black)The Fuji pictures are more color saturated and sharper in general, but the Canon A480 takes better close-up (macro) shots.  You are able to get closer to your subject with the Canon, so if you are solely wanting to take close-up pictures, I think the Canon may be a better choice for you.If you play around with the J28, you will be able to get some halfway decent MACRO shots.  Look at some of my pictures I have uploaded and you can see the difference between the watch shot at 5 MP from 4 inches away and the coin shot at 10 MP from farther and then cropped.  I get my best macro shots from setting the resolution to 10MP Fine, and holding the camera at least 6 inches away from the subject, then cropping it.  Otherwise, they turn out pretty bad.However, for all-around picture taking of vacations, pets, people, and everything else, this Fuji J28 is superior for the following reasons:1. The lithium-ion battery is longer lasting than AA alkaline batteries.  I was able to take 224 pictures before the battery needed recharging.2. J28's colors are brighter and more saturated.3. The J28 LCD screen is slightly larger.4. SR-Auto - (Scene Recognition Auto) Just leave it on this setting and you can't help but take a good picture.5. Flash recycling time is MUCH shorter with the J28 than the A480 - recycling time is the number of seconds after a flash picture has been taken before the camera is ready to take another picture.6. You can use the optical zoom while recording a movie with the J28.  With most cheaper point & shoot cameras, you cannot use the zoom. But you must set the zoom before you start recording, it cannot be changed during recording.7. The menus and buttons are more intuitive with the J28.8. The plastic body of the Fuji J28 seems to be more durable. Just one complaint:  The shiny body shows every fingerprint!Older and more technically challenged people should have no trouble using this camera. On the same note, this is perfect for younger kids too, due to the price. Just set the menu to SR-Auto and six different scenes will be recognized automatically:  Landscape, Portrait, Nightlit Portrait, Backlit Portrait, Night, and Macro. You don't have to do a thing but press the shutter halfway to focus, then once the focus is locked, press the button all the way down.I've taken over 200 pictures with no blurry ones yet.  My hands aren't the steadiest and I have 3 cats that won't hold still and pose for me, yet every picture of them has been perfect with this camera.If I could find something to complain about - and I think this may have to do with the price point of this camera - I would love to have a dial on top to access the settings instead of having to go through the menu.  Also, I'm really disappointed that Fuji can't come up with better photo editing software than what they supply with their cameras, it hasn't changed much at all since 2004 (Picasa is better).  But these are my only complaints, and not enough to warrant a reduction in stars in my rating.I've uploaded some photos taken with this camera, please check them out!

Reviews.Title: I love my J28
Reviews.Author: Katie's Dad
Reviews.Content: I received my Fuji J28 a couple of day ago and I love it!  I decided to buy it over the Canon A480 because the J28 is WAY thinner and also takes a rechargeable battery.  This is the perfect camera for me because the camera has a mode called SR-Auto which will automatically detect 6 different scenes.  It can detect if I take a photo of my kids, a flower or landscape.  I love to hike and the small size makes it east to carry in my pocket.  My photos are very sharp and colorful.This is one of the easiest cameras that I have ever owned because there are only a few buttons on the back and the menu is very intuitive.  There are many advanced features available if you know how to use them.I have already taken over 100 pictures over the last couple of days and I haven't had to recharge the battery.Overall I am very happy with my purchase.  The features and feel and look of the J28 remind me of a more expensive camera.  I would definitely recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera for the value
Reviews.Author: Laura B

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_38896431currentClick) { return cv_38896431currentClick(); } } } Length:: 2:35 MinsThis is a nice little camera. The first thing I noticed about this camera was how light it is. It barely weighs anything, so putting it in my pocket doesn't weigh my pants down. It is also nice and small and doesn't feel bulky when in my pocket. Out of the box it is quick and easy to use.Pros:(1) Easy to use. The Scene Recognition Mode (SR) makes it completely auto--no switching around to landscape or auto mode, etc. while shooting.(2) Light. I don't think I've used a digital camera that is this light before. Even my other cameras with li-ion batteries are heavier.(3) Value. This is a great price for a good camera.Cons:(1) The SR mode can make it a little difficult to focus in macro mode. I tried taking pictures of flowers and it had trouble focusing. Switching to macro mode worked fine.(2) Panoramic mode. In this mode you take 3 pictures to get one long one--you need to line each picture up on the view screen with the previous one you took. I couldn't see on the view screen well enough to match up the edged of each photo to create a good panoramic picture. They all ended up a bit off. (seen the video for examples)(3) The battery compartment lid opened while I was using the camera. The latch seems to be a little too easy to open and because my thumb was positioned right on top of it I would inadvertently open it while taking pictures.(4) Switching between modes is a pain. There is no quick switch button--you must go through the menu to change modes. A little bit of a pain for me, especially when switching between video and still photos.The video shows its size and a few pictures of it. I also took a number of pictures in my back yard and while sailing. I took this camera out with me on our sailboat (an Ultimate 20--a 20' racing boat) during a regatta in the San Francisco Bay and it held up very well. I didn't get it wet, but it stayed in my pocket while I was bounced around, knocked over halfway into the water, and jumped back and forth on the boat. I took a short video of us racing to get an idea of the quality--both video and sound.I would recommend this camera to anyone looking for a less expensive, decent digital camera. It is simple and easy to use for basic shots. I don't think it is good for someone who is an experienced photo-taker (I'm not saying photographer because I mean someone who is an everyday person who takes lots of pictures of everything). For the price, though, it is a great entry-level digital camera.

Reviews.Title: Meet my new BFF
Reviews.Author: C. Scanlon "least helpful reviewer"
Reviews.Content: For over a quarter century I have done photography for publication, including in the war zone of Nicaragua in the time of Reagan.My grandfather was a news photographer, who taught my mother to use the old Speedgraphics 5x7 format outdoors. He did Yellowstone and Mount Rushmore and the Grand Canyon with her long before those were way overdone. He kept a darkroom in the basement I would crawl around.When I was in Nicaragua we used SLR's, mainly manual as that was all that there was, and did black and white darkroom work in the sweltering heat. The preferred camera body back then was the Nikon of course (I had a Canon). The preferred film was Fuji, not Kodak, especially for color slide work (slide, uh, you might not understand that if you're under a quarter century . . .).I had started off with a Kodak Instamatic as a little kid, even a Brownie maybe, learning the basic rules we still must use such as: Keep the sun behind you (although this J28 provides for that if you ask it), fill your frame, the Law of Thirds (which this J28 can easily display at the push of a button - keeping things straight in your frame and at the juncture of the Thirds where they belong, once focus is locked in) - etc., the old golden rules which still apply today, and I went through photography classes from high school through college.This J28 is the best thing I have met, and already was provided me with publishable shots. Of course in today's market I manage to remain obstinately, even proudly, "often published; never paid." And to remain in the war zones.This thing is smaller than a pack of Raleighs, and half as thin, and yet has more power than any camera I have met, within its limitations. And it is intuitive.For instance last Friday before Sunset I was standing at a public service with a few hundred people near the main plaza of a small village in Mexico, a community I have lived with about five years, so they know me. A young girl standing on a fence watching the event I knew to be an observant, thoughtful, capable person with whom I have never actually spoken, but I knew she is bright. And she had the best angle for taking pictures of the crowd, and what was happening in the middle. All I did was hand her this J28. All she did was ask how to zoom in and out (like she knew about that!). And she took the best pictures I have seen, without reading the manual first.I did not trust the digital zoom based on experience with other such "point and shoot" DSLR's which once you pass the point of optical zoom simply blows up the available pixels, making the result blurry. The young girl did not back away, but zoomed away with the digital zoom, and in this J28 the results are NOT blurry, but luminous, in that light of dusk, and crystal clear and crisp.I would have been afraid to take a shot like that, wary of the results, but she went ahead and did it and the results are great.What a camera.This camera by the way comes in a very "green" package, with very minimal plastic except for the heavy duty indestructible stuff around the 2GB SDcard that comes included. I quickly ordered of course a standard sized SanDisk 8GB Ultra II 15MB/s SDHC SD Card Class 4 (SDSDH-008G-P36, Retail Packaging) which this camera had no compatibility problems writing and reading. As part of the "green" the camera comes with a manual on disk, multi-lingual, as well as updates included in print. Lacking a home computer, I printed out the nearly one hundred page manual twice, once blown up to full sheet size. There is more here than you can possibly imagine. It's like your cellphone (I don't know; I don't have one of this generation!); far more features than you will ever actually learn.But this is worth learning. I started out setting everything to AUTO, including flash. Adjusting the flash is very simple for situations in which you either want to force the flash or suppress it entirely (my usual situation - and since this camera can go out to ISO 3200, not merely 1600 - who needs flash!), by just hitting the circle dial right. You can do the same for macro, hitting the dial to the left. Now I have progressed to Scene Recognition, which includes automatic macro, as well as night scenes, landscape, portrait, etc. I hope to have sufficient mastery of this marvelous machine to go to the Manual mode, but prefer for now to trust the on-board sensors. WHO has time to set up the camera before snapping a shot out here in the real world anyway?But I keep studying the Fine Manual in the meantime. It's like going back to school, and is worth it, because this is a darn good camera, and has far more too offer than you could possibly imagine.My greatest struggle fo course with those old manual SLR's a quarter century ago was focus. We would try to cheat by deepening the depth of field, but that made for other compromises. This camera focuses itself, accurately, and has incredible depth of field from front to back. In the old days we thought it very artistic to have only the main subject in focus with the background and foreground out of focus, a minimal depth of field. This camera produces images sharp from front to back.And it has a Face Recognition focus feature. You can watch on the rear display the process of focusing, and can tell when the camera has found a face somewhere in the frame; a green square goes around it. The camera will focus upon that face (or faces) and not lose it (unless of course you choose to turn off the face recognition feature. This is incredible. Where was this a quarter century ago?In fact this camera quickly sets up and shoots. Candid shots are a breeze. Point and shoot. And continuous shots are possible. Time between shots is no more than a few seconds otherwise, normally.It is so small I can slip it into a pocket and no one knows. That is what I need most. I carry it wrapped in a handkerchief and slipped into one of those name tag pouches they pass out at professional conventions. My dream is to go to an optometrist in Mexico and beg for a large metal eyeglasses case to keep it in. Those things are nearly bulletproof and that is just about what I need. Meanwhile the ID pouch is great, and has room for an extra SD card.Normally my gear would also include a set of AA lithium batteries, but another part of the "green" aspect of this camera is that it has a rechargeable battery. This does help keep the camera thinner than a AA battery, but I would hate to lose that charger cord. To charge you plug the cord into the tiny USB port in the camera, and then into the wall. A Red light comes on the back of the camera. When it is charged, the light goes out.The rear display uses the image of a AA battery to indicate present state of power, with little wedges to show how much power is left. I was concerned when the first wedge went out, and wasn't sure whether you had to completely discharge the battery before recharging, or leave the dreaded false memory in the battery. I went for it and recharged, and it seems to have no ill effects.I was able to take hundreds of shots and review and delete, etc., before the battery went low, but this was only a few days. I think the lithiums last longer in the other camera, but I will just have to be attentive to this. I fear losing the rechargeable battery (very small, very thin) or the charger cord, knowing how I am. Also the manual indicates that eventually the battery will burn out; so I might want to get a backup in any case.There really is so much here that I have only barely touched the surface. This camera is fantastic, and takes ten megapixel images. You can also set it up to take much smaller images, and the ten megapixels can be set up for normal or for finer. The next step up in this series is the Fujifilm Finepix J38 12MP Digital Camera with 3x Optical Zoom and 2.7 inch LCD which takes twelve megapixels in this tiny camera, with no apparent loss to quality.Read the manual. There is far more here than I can quickly share at this time and in this forum. I should mention as well that it does movies very well.My last review here was of Japanese Black Pine seeds, and I used this camera to film planting a seed. I used the LOWEST resolution (320) rather than the higher resolution (640) simply for the smaller file produced, meaning less time uploading to amazon. I was not sure how much room would be taken up by the film in any case. As it was, it was a much smaller file than I had imagined. All and all, in both still and film files, this camera produces very economical, small files.You can see at that review there is great depth of field, fine focus even at this lowest resolution, no real loss of quality, and good color balance throughout.An excellent camera, the best one I have, and I also have Nikons in my arsenal (Coolpix and D series).This camera is my new BFF!(OMG!!)

Reviews.Title: Good for beginners, not for those with camera experience and expectations.
Reviews.Author: Jennifer
Reviews.Content: I was really excited to get this camera--I currently have a Canon Powershot SD600 that has started to misbehave and I was ready for a nice, new, snazzy 10MP camera. So how does the Fujifilm FinePix compare? **Let me preface this review by saying that I have read NONE of the manuals that came with the camera. I believe if I can't figure out a simple digital camera without reading the manual, it's probably not the camera for me. Also, there's no paper book--it's all on CD.**Well, first, the actual model number of the camera isn't printed anywhere on the camera, so I had to find my product packaging to see just which version I got (the box tells me it's the J28). That's not a deal breaker, of course, but I just find it odd.One big surprise? There is a tiny bit of internal memory which will allow you to take up to 11 pictures (at the lowest settings) or 1 picture (at the highest setting). I haven't seen a camera with that feature in a LONG time. That might be a bonus for someone who wants to test the camera and doesn't have their own SD card ready to go.A strange thing? This is the first camera I think I've ever seen where the battery can actually fit in more than one way! Now, that doesn't mean it will WORK in more than one way--there is a definite right way to put the battery in to get it to charge. But since I am used to batteries that only fit one way, I put in the battery (it fit!), locked it in, and closed and locked the camera door. And it wasn't charging. Hmmm. Tried another outlet. Still not charging. Unplugged and replugged the charging cable. Nothing. I finally thought to look at the battery and yep, I had it in backwards. I turned it around and the charging started right away. Oh, and yes, there's no battery charger--you leave the battery in the camera and have to plug in a mini USB-looking connection and then plug it into the wall. This action doesn't seem like it would lend itself well to having a backup battery.At first glance, the camera is slick. And thin. And the display screen is HUGE. The button placement seems nice enough--but the first thing I noticed was that there was no video mode! I knew the camera did video, so then I was on the hunt to find it. Well, I found it, and it's buried three screens in (menu, shooting mode, then scroll to Movie). This is a pretty big fault in my opinion, as usually when I decide to take a movie, it's a spur of the moment thing and I just want to flick a switch one-fingered (like on my old Canon). Having to stop to hit a few buttons and scroll to make a selection...well, it might become easier/quicker with time, but I don't like it.The camera boots up/turns on and takes pictures somewhat quickly, but I am finding that it often takes blurry pictures. I think this is mostly due to how long it takes to focus if the subject is moving AT ALL. (Which, I am taking pictures of my 8-month-old, so movement is something I pretty  much always have.) For a bunch of tries, I got a red AF! on the screen which I'm guessing means autofocus isn't working or hasn't yet focussed enough to take the picture (remember, I haven't read the manual). This actually seemed to happen more often than not--very frustrating. Other times you could see the green square jumping around the screen trying to decide what was a face so it could focus. Of the approximately 130 test shots, half were blurry. HALF! That's CRAZY.Something else I was unhappy with? The Picture Stabilization. It's ONLY a "mode" available three screens in (where the Movie mode is). Which means it's not something that's on all the time! This is a BIG fault for me, as this is something that is a default feature on most cameras these days (and not just a selectible mode). But the J28 is more of a budget camera, so I guess they offer some budget settings as well.I also found that if you try to take a second photo too soon after the previous photo, you can't. Plain and simple, it's like you've locked it out and you can hold the button down until the cows come home and it will not take a photo. So I hope you don't want to take pictures in quick succession! I thought it might have to do with viewing the photo on the screen--meaning, if you had the camera set to show the photo for 1.5 seconds, if you tried to take another during that first 1.5 seconds, you couldn't. So I turned off the photo viewing completely--and still had the problem. There doesn't appear to by any rhyme or reason to it... Sometimes I press the button quickly and it snaps a photo. Other times I have to do the halfway-hold to get it to focus and THEN it snaps a photo. Other times I hit the button and...nothing happens. I tested for like 10 minutes trying to figure out what was going on and I just gave up.Then I tested the macro setting. I have taken many macro photos in my life...and I could NOT get a good macro shot to save my life. The closest I could seem to get was about 3-4" away, otherwise it was totally blurry. This distance limitation might just be part of the camera, but even so, I believe a true macro setting should be able to get up to an inch away. Again, this may be part of the "budget" aspect of the camera.The auto scene selection isn't the end-all-be-all that others have said. It seems to pick the wrong setting about half the time. I took two pictures of my dog sleeping on the couch (at a normal distance, maybe three feet). I then zoomed in, not moving, and suddenly it switched to Night setting and the pic turned out blurry. GRRRR. I then took two pictures of my son sitting on the floor. The first setting popped up as Auto and the photo came out okay. The second photo, where I physically moved a bit closer to him, changed to Night setting and came out blurry. WHAT?!? And of course there's no chance of taking a macro shot while on the auto setting (at least that I could see).One somewhat neat thing is that when you move through the menus, you get a short text description on the screen of what the mode is--or when you scroll through the different flash options, it tells you what each one is. That said, I didn't see anywhere to turn those off, and it quickly became annoying.So, overall, I unfortunately have to say I am NOT impressed with this camera. I have been using digital cameras for 10 years so I am not new to their abilities...and while this camera seems able to take some good pictures, it is also not as good as I wanted it to be. It is probably a good camera for a beginner...but for someone with as much experience (and expectation) as someone like me has, it falls a bit short. For now, I think I will go back to using my Canon PowerShot SD600 and give this camera as a gift to a niece or nephew or maybe my mother-in-law. To get the features I want and expect, I'm definitely going to have to go up in price.

Reviews.Title: Impressive pictures for a low price
Reviews.Author: Quoad Toad
Reviews.Content: Before using this camera, I was skeptical about the quality of the pictures from such a low priced camera.  I was shocked that right out of the box, this camera produced nice pictures.The J28 is simple to use.  It's good for beginners who don't want to mess with a lot of settings.  The picture quality out of the box is far better than the out of the box pictures with higher end digital cameras.Users can control important settings, such as ISO.  I like using a low ISO, so that's the only setting I immediately changed.  The flash is quite strong, so using a low ISO is feasible.  On the other hand, the flash remains strong even in areas where the light is more and adequate.The picture quality is nice.  The colors look vibrant, although the camera skews towards pink hues.  The pictures looked great when viewing them at about half their original size on my computer screen.  As I zoomed in to full size and beyond, I could notice fringing and artifacts.  I haven't yet printed pictures from this camera, but I speculate that the pictures will look good as 8x10s and below.The J28 is small and light and can easily fit in a purse or pocket.  The battery seems to last for over 200 pictures.This camera has a lot of good points, but there are a couple downsides - The camera is slow turn on and zooming in and out takes much longer than higher end cameras.  The body is plastic and feels slightly "cheap."  At this price point, these aren't complaints as much as warnings to a potential buyer.Overall, I highly recommend the J28 to anyone who is looking for a simple starter camera.

Reviews.Title: The Price is Right
Reviews.Author: Normal Guy "Happily Married with Children"
Reviews.Content: I will make my review simple and straight to the point. The reason why this camera caught my eye is price.  A name brand camera (Fuji) with 10MP for $79, AND, Amazon gives you a free Fuji 2 GB SD memory card ($9) and a free Case Logic DCB-16 ($9) with it (look for that deal next to the picture of the camera where it says a limited time offer). So top that with my Amazon Prime free shipping and I got a great deal (equivalent to $45 if bought locally). Now for the rest of the story. At first glance, the camera is slick, thin and the display screen is nice size. However, when I gave it to my daughter, who is into youtube, the first thing she said was that she wished I bought her a camera that does video. (?) initially I thought I made a mistake and bought one that does not do video, since looking at the J28, it did not have a video mode button. However, we had to hunt that feature down ... and found it buried three screens in (menu, shooting mode, then scroll to Movie). This is NOT practical in my opinion since video shoots are usually on a spur of the moment.  Still the Price is Right and its a Fuji. The second issue to look out for is that the battery does not go in "one way - the correct way". The slot is not designed to accept a one way.  You can put it in the wrong way and it fits, yet will not charge.  Make sure to line up the two power strips of the battery to the the two charger strips and you're good to go.  All in all, its a non-refurbished Fuji (new), with a large screen, 10MP, 2GB card and a case for a very good price.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: Radar Tech
Reviews.Content: I got this camera several days ago while it was on BF Sale. For the most part I am very pleased. The camera takes very good pictures and has great battery life. The anti-shake or Picture Stabilization mode works well. As some others have stated, you will have to manually select the Picture Stabilization mode if you want it enabled. This camera is small and as others have stated a fingerprint magnet because of the glossy black finish. The fingerprint issue doesn't bother me. The only five negatives that I have are:1: The camera housing is a little too much plastic (most cameras are at this price point).2: The camera close up shots are hard to focus, so forget about any real close up shots within a foot or less.3: Indoor shots that I took mostly have to use a flash under low lighting (pictures came out looking excellent with the flash).4: You have to manually select the Picture Stabilization mode if you want it enabled.5: Plastic battery cover is somewhat flimsy (be careful when opening). Open by pressing down firmly on the cover and then gently sliding cover out away from camera. Too much force will probably break the cover.Aside from the negatives this is still a very nice camera. Overall pictures come out looking excellent. I own Canon and Kodak cameras and I would rate the FinePix J28 as good as anything in its price range compared to those brands. Another thing to mention is that the image stabilization is digital controled on the FinePix J28, not optical. Optical stabilization is considered to be better than digital. I will say that with this camera, the digital image stabilization works great. I deliberately shot some pictures with excessive movement, and all of the pictures came out 100% perfect.Positive Points Are:1: Excellent Battery Life (rechargeable lithium ion).2: Small Battery charger.3: Excellent pictures (outdoor and indoor).4: Excellent digital image stabilization.5: Very nice small camera size.6: Movie mode works very good along with the audio.7: LCD is sharp and vivid.8: Menus are intuitive or easy to understand.9: Shutter lag between shots (with or without flash) is good.10: Good price vs quality + features.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for the Price
Reviews.Author: Timothy J. Dilger "Dilg5"
Reviews.Content: I just bought the Fujifilm FinePix J28 and I can't believe the great pictures I have already gotten.  The Black finish and thin body design makes the camera sleek and stylish.  The J28 really looks and acts like an expensive camera.  I can't believe it cost less then a $100.  I love the Face Detection & the Auto Scene Recognition modes too.  Fujifilm has made an awesome camera for the price. It is so easy to use and the menu is very user friendly.  The Fuji FinePix J28 is simply a great camera for the price!

Reviews.Title: Take fine pics with your Finepix
Reviews.Author: Just ask me! "bronxgal"
Reviews.Content: There are certain attributes which this camera shares with many cameras on the market, so I will mention but not dwell on them:You can't take pictures if your camera isn't with you, so you want a camera which fits in your pocket.You want a big bright screen to see your photos, as you're shooting and to quickly review and determine if you need to take another shot.You want a camera with optical zoom for taking shots and with the capacity to zoom into your photos after you take them to ensure they're what you want, while you can still reshoot.My intent in reviewing this camera was to challenge its simplicity by unpacking  it, assembling it (relax, that's just putting on the strap and inserting the battery and memory card), charging it, taking pictures, and downloading photos to my computer without consulting the instructions or manual.  With one small exception (unlike any other camera I own which uses a battery--and I own several--the battery will go in either way with contacts down, but only one way is correct) I was totally successful in doing this.One major benefit of the FinePix J28 over many other compact point and shoot cameras is that, until the battery needs replacement or you wish to change memory cards, the card and battery stay in the camera.  The camera will charge with the supplied cord, without requiring removal of the battery.The controls are also intuitive.  There aren't so many specialized functions that you get lost. (Disclaimer: I don't need the camera to find faces for me, and didn't test this feature.)  I was able to "setup" for language, date and time without needing to consult the instructions.  The controller then brings you easily into what are the functions you need quickly: flash, macro, self-timer and trash.  (About this last one:  I strongly recommend trashing bad photos as you go, before the task gets daunting.)The FinePix J28 camera has an auto-off feature if it goes unused for awhile, and you may find this annoying, but since the display uses power even when you're not taking pictures, it will save you from having a battery die in the middle of the day.  Given the high capacity of memory cards (my 2GB card holds almost 800 shots at high resolution) you're likely to run out of power before you run out of room for pictures.Outdoor photography can be a challenge, in that with too much sunlight the display is hard to see.  Don't waste your time looking for a point-and-shoot which also has a viewfinder, because they don't seem to be making them anymore.  Just take multiple shots (there's a function for that!) in the right direction and, when you get home to your computer, crop away!  This is a good reason to take your photos in high-res even if you're not planning to enlarge them.The shutter is quick and I've been happy with the shots of people and nature which I've taken so far, including some indoors without flash.The Fuji FinePix J28 camera comes with its own software, but I was successful in downloading photos to my Windows computer by connecting the camera to my desktop via the (supplied) USB cable and moving the files from the camera (which came up as a device in "My Computer") to a file in "My Photos".Now, about that manual.  While the FinePix camera does come with a basic quick-start sheet in many languages (which I didn't consult because I was conducting the "Know-It-All Challenge"), the manual is on a disc.  This is a compact camera meant to be taken away from home and perhaps even away from a laptop.  If Fuji doesn't wish to furnish a paper manual--and I believe they should--the digital one should at least be on a USB thumb drive, so it is accessible on devices (such as netbooks) without disc drives.Back in the day, when I used film cameras, I always preferred Fuji film to the stuff in the yellow box.  Now I'm glad to discover that they've also come up with great digitals.

Reviews.Title: UNRELIABLE camera
Reviews.Author: Shoppinggirl
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in Oct and have had problems off and on.  Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesnt.  Finally I just couldn't get the camera to start.  I took it into Best Buy and turns out the battery was dead.  I got the camera less then 6 months ago.  The battery is $40, which makes this inexpensive camera a little more pricy.  The best buy employee told me that fujifilm cameras are very unreliable and he encouraged me to buy a different camera all together since I am going to Europe and it may stop working durring my trip, even with a new battery.  Don't waste your money!  The picture quality is ok, but the flash blows out the pictures (better for natural light shots).

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera with a Small Price Tag!
Reviews.Author: D'Backs '98
Reviews.Content: I just received the J28 as a gift because my old camera broke.  This camera is perfect for me because I need an auto-everything camera.  Right out of the box I was able to take great pictures.  The face detection works great.  I take lots of pictures of my granddaughter.  My husband uses more complicated cameras.The buttons and the menu are easy to understand even though I don't change many settings.  I change the flash settings and use the macro for close ups but that's about all.  I just discovered this great feature call SR-Auto.  This setting will determine what kind of photo that you are taking - Portrait, Landscape, Macro, Night, night Portrait and Backlight Portrait.Compared to my old 4MP camera the images are extremely clear.  The battery lasts way longer than AA batteries.This camera does more than my old camera, which I paid about $300.  I forgot to add that the camera is super thin which allows me to easily carry it in a pocket or my purse.For the price the J28 is a steal!

Reviews.Title: An amazing camera in its price range.
Reviews.Author: Nick "whereishawkins"
Reviews.Content: I ended up picking this camera up as a gift, and I did what every bad sibling should do: play with it before I gave it as a gift. I know, total jerk move on my part. Mainly I was interested in how it fared against my other Canon cameras, and for the most part, it held its own.1) The battery life was pretty awesome. 100+ photos, most with flash, and it was still going strong.2) I didn't bother reading the manual, and it was rather quick to get used to. Easy to use.3) As expected, high ISO photos are pretty noisy. Consider this as a last ditch effort.4) The LCD is bright and crisp, and playback is pretty straight forward.5) Charging in the camera is pretty cool.6) The camera is about the size of a deck of playing cards. I've got big hands, and I had no problem operating anything on it.I didn't evaluate the software because I used Picasa and iPhoto (for Windows and Mac, respectively). I ended up doing some minor color correction because I found that the photos were a little too warm for my liking.Overall for the price, it's pretty slick. Makes me wish I needed a pocket sized camera so I could have got this for myself as a nice adjunct to my other cameras.

Reviews.Title: Sexy. Easy to use.
Reviews.Author: Erich Maria Remarque
Reviews.Content: In one sentence: I love this cam!Aesthetics: It's very small and can easily fit into pant pockets. It's comparable in size to a "fat" wallet. Additionally, the attractive black plastic feels durable. It definitely looks more expensive than the current $100 price tag (the shiny black color helps in that regard). The LCD screen is huge, bright, and clear, though real time video playback is a bit choppy. But again this camera is really thin, and that's the most obvious feature as far as aesthetics go.Functionality: If you keep everything on Auto, most of your pictures will be almost perfect. If you want more control, the camera offers some basic manual options, including White Balance adjustment, exposure compensation, and manual ISO selection (keep this one on 100 for best quality). Personally, I will be keeping the J28 on Auto for quick photo shooting, and use an older Canon A590IS camera for manual shots. Video capture quality is Ok at 640x480 (with sound), but then again this is not a camcorder. If you don't want to dig into any of the options, the camera is very intuitive to use when set in Auto mode. It's simply the familiar task of pointing the camera, pressing the button halfway and waiting for the auto-focus, and then pressing the button all the way down. That's it. Perfect for technologically-challenged folks. ;)It doesn't require any drivers on Windows 7 (the only OS I tried it with, but Windows Vista should be the same); it's literally Plug&Play.; Simply connect the USB cord and use the Windows Picture Transfer wizard to get the photos, or you can browse them like you would with a flash drive. Though it does come with a disc containing software (FinePixViewer S v2.1) for both PCs and Mac, but I didn't install it.There are two things that would personally consider negatives. 1) I don't like the fact that this camera uses a rechargable battery (and not AAA), but this more of a personal preference and many people prefer not having to deal with AAA batteries. And 2) it uses a micro-USB connector instead of the more common mini-USB. However, I understand that both these characteristics are found in almost all other thin P&S; cameras, so it wouldn't be fair to remove any stars.Overall, if you are looking for an easy to use, durable camera, which takes good quality stills, the FujiFilm J28 is a recommended choice.

Reviews.Title: Good color quality at a cheap price.
Reviews.Author: TurtleWax
Reviews.Content: This is the 3rd Fuji finepix series camera that I have purchase for myself or others and it is the best yet. Most cameras have problems with fluorescent lights or sodium lights but this one gives accurate colors every time. Focus is nice and sharp and the recharge time for flash is much better than the others. That may be due to the built in LiIon battery pack which gives great battery life. No more buying a brick of AA alkaline batteries for a special occasion. Great deal for the price.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Camera, One gripe..!
Reviews.Author: S. Srinivasan "Shansrinivasan"
Reviews.Content: This is a perfect point and shoot.. and it is low priced. for a low priced camera I did not expect great low light photographs..ofcourse with flash i would expect decent photos and this camera delivers..It even exceeded my expectations in most part. although my expectations were very low. One major thing is, i read in the fuji site that you will be able use ZOOM function in video mode.. however the manual says the focus is set before the start of video recording. not sure which one is correct. bottom line, i am not able to use zoom function in video.. which is a major disappointment for me. I like to hear from you guys if you were able to use the zoom function during video recording. In other respects this camera delivers big time..Very good picture quality. My other camera is DMC-FZ50 ...thats really a heavy and huge camera..i bought this one to take wherever i go.....just point @ shoot pics ad hoc.. this is a great camera to take it /keep it with you alltimes.. so far i have taken several pictures/videos..battery life seems to be great... indicator still shows the more than half charge..i also bought an extra battery for 3 bucks.. i suppose i will never use it..if this battery holds charge like this..very light, too cute.. lighter than my PDA cellphone, and the case that came with this camera fits perfectly, its great..it also has a small zipper , where i put my extra battery, SD cards etc. Also it is advisable to remove the battery/SD card from the camera when not in use.. i put that in that zipper......it would be too much for me ask, if i can put my camera charger in that small bag.. however i can live with that because i have an extra battery that i can put in that zipper.. :) .. As i mentioned before i havent used my extra battery yet.. Soi suppose..this camera can be charged via USB.. havent tried it yet though..So far i am happy with my purchase..i would have given 5 stars if i was able to zoom during video recording...one more thing this takes some good night shots try it out..with night tripod mode..Amazon's shipping needs special mention.. i got the product in just two days..

Reviews.Title: Got Zoom Error -Fixed it
Reviews.Author: Premanand Sivakkolundhu
Reviews.Content: After couple of months of use,suddenly started to get zoom error and luckily able to fix it on my own for now.When ever I press the on switch, the camera switches on ,lens comes forward and immediately retracted back and in the display all it says 'zoom error'.I researched it in the internet and looks like lot of people has similar issue and found few tips on how to fix it.As per few postings,I learned that the problem is due to dust and will not be covered by Warranty (I didn't call Fuji).To fix it,I just pressed the on button and the moment lens comes up I just holded  it tighly using my finger grip so that  lens was  in the open position and avoided retraction.Then I positioned the camera in a face down (lens facing down) position and just dusted off just by shaking and tapping(ofcourse gently)the camera .Suddenly it is started to work and the zoom error is gone.Not sure how long this will work.Other than this problem, the camera is okay for the money.I use it for everyday use to take short videos and photos of my two year old daughter and solves the purpose.But because of the 'zoom error' issue,I will not recommend this camera for reliability reasons.

Reviews.Title: My Wife Finally Dumps Her Kodak Advantix
Reviews.Author: Mr. Allnut "Charlie"
Reviews.Content: I searched far and wide for an easy to use point and shoot digital camera for my wife. She has been using, up till Nov. 2009, her Kodak Advantix. The only thing nudging her away was the fact the film is ending production.This is a woman who cannot operate the tv remote. She hates technology. She loves this camera. Just point, shoot and easy upload. She takes pictures then sends them to Costco to be printed.The delay on digital camera from the time you push the shutter button to the actual picture being taken annoyed my wife to no end. This camera snaps fast, closer to an old fashioned film camera.The photo quality is good, the camera menu fairly easy to use and camera size is a plus, easily toted in her purse. She used it all during the holidays without a hitch.She is in picture heaven, and now moving into the 20th century.....

Reviews.Title: love this little camera
Reviews.Author: John Douglas "crzyhors4"
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for my wife, who seems to be averse to most technologies.  She"s visiting her son in California and just sent some shots of San Francisco and Alcatraz.  The shots of Alcatraz from an unsteady platform,were stunning.  Crisp, clear, sharp with that great Fuji color.  I had set the camera mode on scene recognition and  so far every shooting scenario  seems quite accurate.  By the way the video capture with sound is also very good.This a great buy for the novice or the more advanced who just wants something that fits in the pocket for those unexpected moments.....A great value.

Reviews.Title: Great camera in its class
Reviews.Author: Parviz Ghofrany "pg"
Reviews.Content: This is a good camera and takes good pictures.  It can not compete with SLRs but I bouight this for its size and portability.  When I need great quality pictures, I take my canon rebel SLR instead of this.  However for every day pictures this is a good camera.

Reviews.Title: Enjoying it
Reviews.Author: cecil
Reviews.Content: Great camera, very user friendly, crisp pictures, and great battery life. I definately made a good choice with this camera. I have two pictures also posted up to show the picture quality.

Reviews.Title: Takes great pictures!
Reviews.Author: Happy Driver
Reviews.Content: We bought this little camera for a college student.  It takes great photos and is easy to use.  Had many nice features as well.  A good buy for this item.  Would reccommend to others.

Reviews.Title: best camera purchase I've ever made
Reviews.Author: Ann L. Agnew
Reviews.Content: this camera was very easy to use.  takes great pictures. would definitely recommend others to purchase.  I happen to get the memory card and carry case with camera for a great steal.  I should have purchased two

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!
Reviews.Author: L. Stadler
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I needed a camera that was easy to carry and use. I have two grandsons and wanted to be ready at all times to take their pictures.  The pictures come out beautiful and clear.  I took pictures while we were driving on the expressway and all of the pictures were perfect. I have a big camera that will do everything but is bulky and not always easy to use. I read reviews on different cameras and decided on this one.  The battery is rechargeable and lasts a long time. Amazon is a great place to buy.  The package arrived within a couple of days and was free shipping!

Reviews.Title: Great gift!
Reviews.Author: Eric J. Lawrence "Eric Lawrence"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera as a gift for my son for Christmas. It took him about two and a half hours to figure everything out, and now he's taking pictures about as well as any expencive camera would. great product.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix J28 Camera
Reviews.Author: R. TORRES
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for Christmas this year and was quite impressed with this little camera. It is very compact but the battery life on it lasts really long. We went the whole day taking pictures with it and there was no dead battery. It was easy to connect to the computer and upload the pictures, as well as it charged off the USB port on the computer too. The quality of pictures was substantially better than our old camera. We hd a 7mp Camera and could instantly see better quality pictures with this camera. I also liked the speed at which it took pictures. Too many times we have had to have the kids hold still for longer periods as the camera attempted to take pictures. This camera took the picture the moment you pressed the button, which is great for us with small kids who have small attention spans. I'd recommend this camera for anyone.

Reviews.Title: Better Than Expected!
Reviews.Author: L. Guarriello
Reviews.Content: I really needed a point-and-shoot camera so that I don't always need to lug around my other camera.  Have had it for a little over a month and have taken a little over a hundred pictures with it so far.  For the price, I am happily surprised with the quality and overall ease.  I absolutely love it! I also haven't needed to charge the battery yet, which is a pleasure in comparison to always changing the rechargeables  in my other one.  Can't wait to use it at Christmas dinner later!

Reviews.Title: great buy
Reviews.Author: Jacqueline King "Jak"
Reviews.Content: Very easy to use. I love the size it just slips into my purse and off I go. I would recommend this camera to anyone. This is my first camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Value For The Money
Reviews.Author: D. Mcbride
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  It's small enough to drop in my purse or jacket pocket, yet the display and menu items are large enough to make it user friendly (without reading glasses).  Takes really good outdoor pictures.  Indoor shots requiring flash are acceptable, but slightly less than great. Menu is easy to understand, and transferring pic's to computer is very simple.I purchased this camera to take on a trip to New York City, because I didn't want to be encumbered with my larger Kodak (Z712, with 10x zoom).  A friend who accompanied me on the trip purchased a Nikon Coolpix. We took many pictures at the same time, under the same conditions, of the same subject.  After comparing our pic's, I was pleased to find that my Fuji consistently produced better pictures than the Nikon. In fairness, it could be that my friend didn't use the appropriate settings for her camera, but I also noticed the Nikon seemed more complicated, and not as user friendly.I would highly recommend this camera for anyone looking for a functional, practical, fun to use point and shoot camera at a great price.  It's my new favorite camera.

Reviews.Title: Nice, basic camera at a great price
Reviews.Author: bjm "bjm"
Reviews.Content: I ordered this camera on Thanksgiving Day and was able to take advantage of a terrific combo of camera + case + memeory at $20 less than the current price of the camera.  Even paying the full price, it's loaded with nice features and technology available in competitor models for higher prices.Takes nice pictures....high resolution....large memory size with the SD card.  Even comes with an internal memory to hold a limited number of pictures without the card.  Easy to operate....intuitive procedures.  Ended up being a great replacement for my old Fuji Finepix that was beginning to fail.

Reviews.Title: Family snapshot deal
Reviews.Author: M. Young
Reviews.Content: This Fujifilm camera replaced my five year old 2 MP model that had survived kid fingerprints and less that ideal care. I was looking for a camera with more MP, a larger screen, smaller size and that did not use AA batteries. At the affordable price this fits the bill.Positives:SD card makes it easy to transfer to computerBattery life is good and charges by plug-in.Menus are easy to navigatePictures come out beautifulFace recognition works wellCould Improve:Its small size and slick plastic make it hard to hold on toBlack shiny color attracts a lot of dustButtons are also very small (even for a woman with average size hands)I guess you have to give up some ease of use with the small size. I'm always accidentally hitting a button when attempting to play back the pictures or work with the menu. Once you are in picture taking mode there are grips to hold on to the camera. I would recommend this for taking family snapshots and hauling around on vacation.

Reviews.Title: A Delightful Camera
Reviews.Author: Roger M. Pell
Reviews.Content: This camera is the best digital camera I've come across, particularly at the price point I bought. It is easy to master, including interface with my PC to store pics. Picture quality is excellent.

Reviews.Title: Feature packed, neat design features, good camera at a good price.
Reviews.Author: austin_Larry
Reviews.Content: Confessions of a point and shooter; I grew up with photography as a big hobby and was committed to SLR photography and developing my own photos. Over the years I kind of slipped away and when digital photography started to blossom I started getting point and shoot cameras. I now also have a DSLR which I love. I love the quality, the control, the options, the creativity. But here is my confession, I still probably use the point and shoot cameras in our house more. They are just so easy to use, easy to manage (fit in a pocket), and produce good results. They can also capture video something my particular DSLR can not do. If you absolutely had to give me a choice of one digital camera I would stay with my DSLR. But as I said I use my point and shoot cameras more frequently as the way things seem to work out; short road trips, camping, day at the ballpark, etc. they are just easier to use a lot of the time. So there is a definite place for a point and shoot camera for almost everyone.The J28 is a solid performer with a lot of great features that are very useful to the consumer that happens to be at a good price. That is important, a good price doesn't mean anything if the camera can not perform. First it captures colors well with good saturation in most situations. For me after a few weeks of use, I got consistently good results indoors and good to ok results outdoors. In tricky outdoor lighting situations on automatic scene recognition (which most people will use most of the time) you are not going to get perfect exposure. But the colors outdoors were well represented and I appreciated the detail, it has a good quality lens.Cool features: the J28 has a number of really neat features especially at its price point. First is a rechargeable battery that can be re-charged inside the camera. A charge lasts a long time. The camera is also small and lightweight although it has a more plastic feel to it than digital ELPH cameras from Canon that I have used and still use. The menu system is easy to use and you have some cool options I have not seen on other point and shoot cameras. You can actually crop a picture during view picture mode. It was pretty easy to do. It also has a panorama feature that lets you `stitch' 3 pictures together (I have had this on other point and shoot and I like it). The J28 takes decent video but like many point and shoots you can not zoom once you start taking the video. The scene recognition mode works well and I have taken some decent close-ups using the macro mode.The primary draw back is as mentioned before it has real trouble in tough exposure situations. Also the included software literally did not work for me. It installed correctly, the drivers installed correctly, but the software would not download pictures from the camera. I have had well over a dozen point and shoot cameras over the years and this has never happened to me. On windows it was no big deal, the computer did recognize it as a storage device and I got the pictures out easily enough. It was definitely odd though.Bottom line is a well-thought out consumer point and shoot. Are there better point and shoot cameras out there that produce better shots? Yes. Are there many cameras out there that produce the well reproduced colors of shots this camera does and include so many useful and neat features in a very small and lightweight package at this price point? No. This will definitely be in my pocket for a long time, very easy to take, and be there when I need it and I most likely would not have brought my DSLR along.

Reviews.Title: Excellent inexpensive everyday camera
Reviews.Author: J. SPIEGEL "Joe"
Reviews.Content: Fujifilm FinePix J28 10MP Digital Camera with 3x Optical ZoomThis camera is a joy to use. I love that it's so small, I bought a belt pouch for it and can easily take it with me. It certainly can fit in almost any pocketbook. At a price around $100 (as of this writing) it's a bargain. It takes very good pictures and with 10 Megapixels of resolution you can edit and crop and still have an excellent result. The big rear screen is bright and clear in all but the brightest outside areas. The menu structure is easy and relatively powerful for a "consumer" camera. I personally miss a parallax viewfinder but the future of these cameras is LCD.I might pick a nit over the lack of a started SD card but they're so cheap now I won't just remember to get at least a 2GB one to use.  There is internal memory but just get a card. My Windows 7 PC recognized it without issue and imports the pictures into my pictures folder. The charger and data cable are included and work as expected.  It uses a battery pack instead of standard batteries. It's a bit restricting but holds a long charge and should be just fine.Maybe it's me, I just can't get over the fact that this many quality and fun features is in a below $100 camera. This will make a great Holiday gift that won't break the bank. Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: Sleek stylish FinePix!
Reviews.Author: rbhatta "A Dinosaur you can trust!"
Reviews.Content: Fujifilm is not new to the world of cameras they have been delivering good quality cameras for years now, Fujifilm FinePix J28 reviewed here is an excellent little camera for the price tag. The pictures taken by this camera is sharp, clear, bright & vivid with natural colors.Before getting this FinePix J28, I had purchased Fujifilm Finepix A900which is comparatively bulkier and slow. Agreed that as every year goes by Digital cameras get smaller, faster and include more features, FinePix J28 is no exception, it is a simple to use Point and shoot camera with tons of shooting modes to satisfy every `environment one can imagine.PROS[+] Sleek and stylish mirror black finish[+] Fast Startup time (Ready in 2-3 seconds)[+] Very good Quality pictures[+] Decent battery life (takes more than 200 snaps in one charge)[+] No need for taking battery out to charge (One less item to carry)[+] Flash gets ready fast for continuous snaps[+] Very portable travel charger[+] Plethora of shooting modes including In-camera panorama stitchingCONS[-] Plastic but sturdy construction[-] Uses Proprietary Li-Ion Battery NP-45A[-] Noticeably nosier Lens mechanism[-] Does not capture in true 16:9 for displaying on Flat screen TVs[-] MACRO photography is not so good.What I really like about this camera is the Lithium Ion battery can be charged while it is still inside the camera, when you are going on a trip, you can easily forget the separate travel charger module and the power cord as seen in most cameras in this price range. I am sure someone will come up with a Car charger cable and USB cable soon to charge the camera on the go!The provided tiny power converter directly plugs into camera for charging - excellent! Thanks Fujifilm! - The camera is priced right for its features! Go get one!

Reviews.Title: Good Product...
Reviews.Author: Duane
Reviews.Content: found it to be very sturdy and does exactly as expected as advertised, great pictures, great battery and easy to use. I like it and use it...try it  :-)

Reviews.Title: good standard camera
Reviews.Author: Richard Guida
Reviews.Content: While there are many models of digital cameras, this basic, inexpensive one can go the job well. If you are watching your budget, it's great.

Reviews.Title: Nice digital camera
Reviews.Author: carlos
Reviews.Content: This camera is very use easy for to operate. the camera is pretty and let you take good pictures. 100 % recommended

Reviews.Title: Battery went dead
Reviews.Author: Ross D. Bryant
Reviews.Content: Battery went dead right when it was out of warranty.  I kind of felt like it should have lasted longer than that.

Reviews.Title: Great buy
Reviews.Author: E. Santiago
Reviews.Content: I got this little camera for about $90 in a super deal and even if it had been more expensive it is still a great product and totally worth it. Rechargeable battery which lasts VERY long. Takes video, nice pictures, manual mode, not to the degree of a pro level camera but enough to get your feet wet in learning how it works (perfect if you're thinking of taking photography as a hobby), many automatic modes for conditions, panoramic mode, face detection and stabilizes the image.Honestly a great little product, works great and very slick looking.

Reviews.Title: Great, easy to use, point-and-shoot
Reviews.Author: J. James "Jinny Lee"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera on a gold box special two years around the holidays. It's quickly become my go-to camera. The camera has been all over the country and I carry it in my purse everyday, so, needless to say it gets a lot of use and it isn't always treated so nicely. It's held up excellently, though I did have to replace the battery after a year and a few months of steady use.

Reviews.Title: takes decent pics
Reviews.Author: TM
Reviews.Content: After what 2 years?  Still works great.  Happy I bought it.  Fast shipping too.  Not sure what else to say other than it functions as intended.  It's a point and shoot so don't expect amazing pics.

Reviews.Title: Cheap camera, less money=less value
Reviews.Author: SPT
Reviews.Content: This was my first digital camera. Since I had very less ideas about the cameras, I went for this cheap camera. Picture quality was great. It delivered what it said for the first 4 months, then suddenly zoom error started appearing, when it was switched on or when zoomed. Then after some days lens didn't come out from the camera with zoom error when camera was switched on. However, after many tries of ON-OFF, camera worked perfectly well.After some months picture quality became reddish pink, may be because it got some raindrops in it. Zoom error continued to come. I contacted their customer support, but they were not much friendly.I put this camera aside, as I do not use too much camera. After some months (2 or 3) when I switched on the camera, everything worked perfectly well. Picture quality was as it was before, when I bought it. Zoom error comes a while, when I zoom the camera. But every other thing works perfectly well now.I gifted this camera to my younger brother, and I have ordered Nikon coolpix, which is great so far.Conclusion: This camera may be right for you, if you are looking for a cheap camera. And if you are lucky enough (camera doesn't gives zoom error etc.), it will be a good buy.

Reviews.Title: Easy First Timer Digital Camera
Reviews.Author: Jennybean
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera as a gift for my mom who is technology challenged & she has a great time with it! Pretty simple, comes with some photo changing features but you dont need to use them.

Reviews.Title: fun at a bargain
Reviews.Author: Gautam Ganguly "online shopper"
Reviews.Content: what a fun camera and a great price. I bought several as gifts and everyone was happy!

Reviews.Title: Great value for a 10.2 MP camera
Reviews.Author: Kal-El85
Reviews.Content: I like this camera. The construction feels a little flimsy but seems to hold up so far (been 3 months). Great battery life!My only complaint is the sliding battery/memory card cover. It is really flimsy. Sometimes, I open it by mistake while taking a shot. Minor problem compared to the overall good value.

Reviews.Title: digital camera
Reviews.Author: L. Davis
Reviews.Content: Fuji was the recommended name for a digital camera from a wildlife photographer we had the pleasure of meeting.  We are quite pleased to date with our purchase.

Reviews.Title: New camera for my son
Reviews.Author: Kari "Kari"
Reviews.Content: Very good value for your money. I gave it to my son for Xmas. He is 13 years old, and the camera was just what he needed: easy to use, easy to bring to school outings, good quality pictures, AND IT RECORDS VIDEOS! He is very happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera
Reviews.Author: NM
Reviews.Content: I've been looking for something small, compact and easy to operate.  I've found it in this camera.  It fits almost anywhere- a pocket or purse and you won't know it's there!  The pictures are great, the battery life is quite good and that's all I can handle.  Perfect!

Reviews.Title: Nice for the price
Reviews.Author: M. Sistare
Reviews.Content: To be fair, I gave this camera as a gift; the price and bundle offered at the time of purchase made it hard to pass up.  I've not printed many pics from it, but those that I have printed (snapshots) look fine.  It's pretty straightforward to use as a point-and-shoot, and it's small but seems easy to hold when taking pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great bang for buck
Reviews.Author: Sudheer Vemula
Reviews.Content: I'm extremely impressed with quality of the camera compared to the price I've paid. Very nice.

Reviews.Title: Good camera...with a small flaw.
Reviews.Author: M. Graham
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my boyfriend for Christmas for his trip to Costa Rica & Panama.  I have the older version of the same camera (8mp) so I was thrilled to find an awesome deal on this one for him.  During his 10 day trip he never had to charge the camera so the battery life is great.  Downloading pictures is simple and the quality is good.  The only downside is there was a dead pixel on the LCD screen.  It doesn't affect the picture quality but it's annoying none the less.

Reviews.Title: Great for the price
Reviews.Author: Brandon M
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my mother as a christmas gift and so far she has loved it!  It is easy for her to use since she likes to use the simple products, and the quality of the pictures are great for the price!  The only downfalls are that it doesn't take the greatest pictures while inside and this camera is a finger print magnet.  Another quality I liked is how slim this camera is!  I didn't know how small it was until I took it out of the box(Of course I had to peek). If your looking for a pocket camera for a great value, this is the camera to buy!

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: TK
Reviews.Content: Purchased this for my father for Christmas and he loves it. Very simple to use, just point and shoot and you get awesome looking 10 megapixel images. Added a 8gb card and camera will now hold around 3100 images. Big screen makes it easy to see what you're looking at, and the face recognition is a neat feature too. For what I paid this thing is a steal!

Reviews.Title: awesome product
Reviews.Author: C. Eres
Reviews.Content: great camera, and a great value. the only weird thing is you have to charge the battery while its inside the camera.

Reviews.Title: Solid Product
Reviews.Author: A Customer
Reviews.Content: This is a solid prodcut for the price.  It is easy to use and takes good pictures.  If you are looking for a standaad product with not a lot of features, this is it.

Reviews.Title: Excellant camera!
Reviews.Author: Brian Winders
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my kid for xmas and after trying it  out I bought one for myself. What a great camera! The pictures are sharp and the camera is easy to use with a lot of different settings or just put on auto. I wanted a camera that was small enough to fit in my pocket that took good pics. This camera is that and more!!

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: H. Roman "romanempire"
Reviews.Content: For the price, this is a very good camera. Takes great pictures, easy to use, very compact.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera!
Reviews.Author: K. Kenney
Reviews.Content: I bought two of these for my daughters for Christmas.  Both of them love the small size and say they're easy to operate.  Picture quality is great!

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm camera
Reviews.Author: Paul B.
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my daughter, and she loves it. Takes great pictures, and the battery lasts a long time.

Reviews.Title: LOVE IT!!
Reviews.Author: V. Lucas
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my Hubby as a Christmas gift.  I have owned a couple of digital cameras myself, but this is his first. I played with it quite a while before I wrapped it.  I ended up liking it BETTER than the one I currently own! This camera explains EVERY setting on it...and it has settings for EVERY environment! It took BEAUTIFUL pictures of our Christmas tree...showing the natural light.  It seems to work well in all types of lighting.  Its even smaller than mine!! The viewing screen is almost as large as the entire backside of the camera.  It is really a GREAT camera for the price! I want one for myself now!!!

Reviews.Title: Nice camera!
Reviews.Author: Leslie Thomas
Reviews.Content: This is a great little camera. Bought it in a bundle for my teen nieces for Christmas and they LOVE it! It's very light weight and thin. Take good pictures and the screen to view them on is large and a good quality. Quite happy - would definitely recommend to others.

Reviews.Title: very easy to use, sleek design, recommended purchase
Reviews.Author: J. Hecker
Reviews.Content: I am definitely glad that I bought this camera. It takes great pictures and loads really fast. The turnaround time between turning the camera on and taking pictures is very, very fast. the sleek design is really cute and easy to carry around. I got the black one and it shows every little smudge and fingerprint on it but I don't really care about that. I would definitely recommend keeping it in a case, because it gets switched on by accident if you have it loose in your purse or your pocket. then the battery runs out and your are left wondering why.

Reviews.Title: VERY HAPPY!
Reviews.Author: J. Wood "JoJo"
Reviews.Content: This was a Christmas gift for the wife ...she loves it. It's easy to use, and takes some very nice quality pics!

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: RSR
Reviews.Content: This replaced a 2004 Fuji 3.2 megapixel camera that had worked flawlessly for 5 years. I can`t believe how small this one is, and WOW, what a jump from the tiny screen on my old one! The controls will be familiar to current Fuji owners, easy to use with respectable picture quality. An all around nice camera for the occasional photographer.

Reviews.Title: Great camera great price.
Reviews.Author: Bummer 2
Reviews.Content: Excellent camera for the price. Would be an overall better value if the camera bag was a mite larger.

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: Modie "Modie"
Reviews.Content: Great deal for the money.  I bought this camera for my teenaged son.  I love it so much I wish I would have gotten one for myself.  It's really easy to use, and takes great quailty pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great!
Reviews.Author: Alexis T. Allen "Alexis"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  It was very affordable and the pictures are of a great quality.  I love the richness of the images.  Get one!

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: A. Johnson
Reviews.Content: Love this camera. Easy to charge, just plug in camera with battery still inside.Easy to learn to use. Great first camera!

Reviews.Title: fugifilm finepix J28
Reviews.Author: bargain shopper "Karen"
Reviews.Content: Great camera for the money.  Purchased this for my kids instead of disposables...they love it and it takes great pictures and videos for the money...saves money on developing all the pictures they take.

Reviews.Title: An excellent purchase
Reviews.Author: Ping Hu "Howard Parker"
Reviews.Content: Really easy to use. Battery can sustain for long time. I took almost 200 pictures with only one block of battery. Picture quality is fine. Considering its price, the camera is excellent.

Reviews.Title: GOOD CAMERA for little money
Reviews.Author: Jacob E. John
Reviews.Content: Excellent Digital camera for less than [...] bucks.Picture quality is as good as my more expensive Cannon.Good construction,easy to use and a decent battery life. [...].

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money!
Reviews.Author: Mom5
Reviews.Content: I bought three of these cameras as Xmas gifts for my three teenage/older daughters.  They love it!

Reviews.Title: Affordable Digital Camera with good enough quality.
Reviews.Author: T. N. Tran "Chong"
Reviews.Content: Photos with flash only good for pictures within 10 ft. There's a red push with flash photography; easily fixed with photoshop. Haven't tried any pictures without flash since I mostly use it for night shots. LCD screen is a good size, however its' viewing angle is very narrow. Overall, not bad for a camera that only cost $80. Didn't have to pay tax or shipping. I bought this camera to replace my $350 Casio Exlim that was stolen. I wanted a camera that was cheap and took pictures to post on Facebook and not have to worry about it being stolen again.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Toscano
Reviews.Content: Cannot give an in depth review as the camera was purchased as a gift but from little I saw it appears to be a good camera at a great price. Large screen and ultra compact.

Reviews.Title: Pocket Camera
Reviews.Author: CiggyRN "momx3"
Reviews.Content: Neat little camera. I bought this for an upcoming trip so that I don't have to lug a larger camera around Washington D.C.  The purchase was a bundle of camera, SD card, and case. Excellent value for the $$. I love the size. It fits easily into a pocket. I  also love that it does not have a separate lens cover to fool with. Standard 3x zoom is okay. The video feature has fair picture and good sound but difficult to work through the menu to activate.Overall - this is a terrific camera for a teen or something you want as an easy take-along camera.

Reviews.Title: great price
Reviews.Author: Laura K. Boucher
Reviews.Content: came still in packaging and works great. the only thing that stinks is there is no video mode. other than that though it is a great camera for a cheap price. no problems yet.

Reviews.Title: Good for flash closeups
Reviews.Author: John Montgomery
Reviews.Content: Camera takes great indoor flash pictures.I like the auto red eye fix.Can't beat it for the price.

Reviews.Title: excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Sahaida
Reviews.Content: a must buy. very good price.  Nice pics. I'm new to digital cameras. Just upgraded from a 5 to 10.2MP . very pleased.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for a Great Price
Reviews.Author: Stephen A. Williams
Reviews.Content: Was able to pick this camera up for $79.00 and made a great Xmas Gift.  If you are looking for a camera that will give you good pictures and aren't a professional photographer, this is a good camera to have.  Very light weight.

Reviews.Title: Review!!
Reviews.Author: G. Olsen
Reviews.Content: It worked very very very well and I got the product on a timely manner

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: MontyKupo "..."
Reviews.Content: The camera is an amazing piece of tech for the price. It gets the job done, but the only complaint I have...it is way too shiny.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Daniel Cash
Reviews.Content: So far (2 weeks) this camera has worked well.  Some of the pictures indoors seem to be lacking a bit of light from the flash, but everything else seems to be working fine.  Setup is easy, and all in all it's a good camera for the money.

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: J. Ward
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my 17yrs daughter for Christmas and she absolutely loves it.  The picture quality is fantastic and very easy to use.  She loves the small compact size, ease of charging the camera and the length of time of the battery.  She uses the video recorder with no problems and she can take pictures all day without worries of constantly changing the battery like the cameras that uses AA batteries.

Reviews.Title: So much worth it
Reviews.Author: Erikson Taparan
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as I was eying for a cheap yet good point-and-shoot and my expectations were even exceeded!It's a good camera, with simple yet intuitive interface.Photos are good even in low light, although the color is a little more saturated than actual.The camera has a Li-ion battery unlike other cheap cameras that uses AA battery.And it's Windows 7 compatible! My Windows 7 PC detected it instantly upon plugging.Over-all, I am very much satisfied with it.And I also got a 2 GB Fujifilm SD Card and a Case Logic camera Case FOR FREE!!!!!Imagine that. Cheap, Great and with freebies.. What more can you ask for?

Reviews.Title: so far so good
Reviews.Author: cool guy
Reviews.Content: I got this camera to replace my sony cybershot and so far its good and worth the money. I havent explored all the options yet. Took few shots during the day time and also in snow and its good. Auto scene recognition is okay, but sometimes it is better to switch to manual mode or custom specific mode. Night time pictures are little grainy. But you can over come by setting the flashing.. audio from the video movies are not audible when played from the camera. well,You can expect wonders with camera that is less than 100 $.

Reviews.Title: Great value and easy to use
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth Grenga "lg"
Reviews.Content: This camera is very easy to use and the picture quality is great.  Would buy this again and again

Reviews.Title: Nifty camera for everyday use
Reviews.Author: D. Tsai "Hardware Guy"
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera to be put in the car for emergency purpose. So far, I have been able to use it from time to time to capture beautiful sceneries without the fear of not having the battery power. I bought another battery just in case. The only gripe is that the battery must be charged inside the camera with the USB power - no separate charger for it, unless you buy it from eBay.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Ken Scott
Reviews.Content: Love the picture quality!! Small and lightweight. Lots of automatic shutter/flash settings so no matter how much or little you know about photography, you'll always get great shots. Perfect for everyday use. I HIGHLY recommend this Camera.

Reviews.Title: Very decent point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Nuknuk
Reviews.Content: The J-series, as announced by the manufacturer is one of Fuji's latest line of digital cameras, targeting consumers who are on a budget who do not want to sacrifice quality and style. The 10 megapixel resolution on this tiny-winy camera put my Rebel to shame. Fuji's point-and-shoots are known for their low light ability and it looks like they still are.I always consider a DSLR as the camera of choice if you have the time to study your subjects and want more control for creativity, but a point-and-shoot is best if you want less hassle and don't have the time to fool with the controls.One of the most powerful tools on this camera that is not normally found on other cameras is the Scene Recognition. Cameras today are getting more and more foolproof, this function is another innovative step to achieve that goal. It automatically choose for you the best settings out of the 6 shooting modes base on what you are shooting at. Face recognition is also very handy, it makes sure that the focus and exposure will be based on your people subjects.I normally prefer the regular low-disharge AA or AAAs so that I can always have a ready back up if I run out of juice.
